awd_abstract_narration:
WAR, SOCIETY AND DEMOCRACY

 
The project offers a systematic assessment of the social forces sustaining support for political freedoms in states under military attack. Whereas most existing research emphasizes domestic factors, this study will undertake an innovative examination of external impacts on public support for democratic institutions and practices under wartime conditions. New survey data will be collected and analyzed, and the findings will provide new insights into wartime public opinion and how allies through their policies can help sustain support for democracy under the difficult conditions of war.  

The researchers will utilize a panel design for three waves of surveys to be conducted over the course of one year. Data will be collected on respondents’ preferences for political freedoms and institutions, and on specific war impacts on individuals, expectations of war duration and outcome; pride in citizenship; international alliance preferences; perceived threats to their security and state security; and transnational media impacts. Advanced quantitative techniques will be used to estimate between- and within-subject effects of war onset and duration on democracy support with controls for potential confounders. The findings will contribute to basic research on wartime public opinion, wartime alliances, and the resilience of democracy under wartime conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project provides systematic assessment of the social forces sustaining support for political freedoms and for democracy as a system of government in states under military attack from expansionist autocracies. We use survey and focus group data from Ukraine before and after Russia’s February 2022 full-scale invasion and at different phases of the ongoing war through mid-2024. In collaboration with Ukraine’s National Academy of Sciences Institute of Sociology, three waves of opinion surveys broadly representative of the population under Ukraine’s government control were conducted in June 2023 (N=1,273), December 2023/January 2024 (N=865), and May/June 2024 (N=561), including the same 477 respondents interviewed in all three waves and 455 interviewed in at least one of those three waves as well as in the earlier polls in June/July 2022 and November 2021. This rich panel data enables us to assess the impact on the same individuals of Russia’s all-out invasion and of major changes in a protracted Russia-Ukraine war. To get a better sense of what drives public views we also conducted four focus groups twice (September 2023 and March 2024), each time with one in Kyiv and Kyiv Oblast, Lviv and Ivano-Frankivsk, Mykolaiv and Odesa, and Kharkiv and Donetsk Oblast (8 participants in each regional group).
 

The Project has generated empirical data to test, re-examine, and develop theoretical models in political science and sociology explaining public legitimation of democracy as a political system and individual freedoms with a more refined understanding of perceptual microfoundations and the physical and psychological impacts of war and specifically of a protracted and globally polarizing interstate war.  Significant data has been generated on symptoms associated with the post-traumatic stress disorder to contribute to research on psychological effects of protracted war.

We find that Ukrainians have maintained an overwhelming preference for democracy as a form of government and freedom of speech (expressed by approximately 80 percent of respondents across survey waves), sustaining the initial surge in support following Russia’s full-scale invasion. The persistence of democracy support nearly two years after mid-2022 indicates that the pre/post-invasion surge we observed from 2021 to 2022 was more than a rally, likely constituting a fundamental shift in social attitudes.  

Support for Ukraine joining international coalitions that require new members to adhere to democratic norms has remained strong, with around 80 percent of respondents consistently favoring joining the EU and NATO. Both longitudinal and cross-sectional regression analysis also shows that desired membership in the geopolitical West is one of the pillars of social support for democracy and political freedoms in Ukraine.

 

Support for political freedoms in Ukraine has remained robust since the 2022 surge through mid-2024 despite over 80 percent of respondents reporting some form of personal war loss (with close to 20 percent reporting at least one family member killed in action) and around 90 percent reporting some form of wartime stress. Moreover, in our longitudinal tests, we find that respondents reporting war losses were more, not less likely to see democracy as important for Ukraine. This finding weighs in favor of considering loss as a measure of external threat to the state and the nation that raises the salience of political freedoms.

 

Political freedoms continued to be a preeminent social value despite a declining sense of the sufficiency of international military and diplomatic support, decreased trust in government, and a softening of belief in Ukraine’s eventual military victory from mid-2022 through mid-2024.

 

Our findings indicate that war’s effects on democracy support are significantly more complex than one might conclude based on studies showing either how war undermines democracy or how war mobilization bolsters democratic resilience. They are context/time-contingent and relational. The results further validate and provide refinements to the theory of geosocietal support for democracy (Mikhail A. Alexseev and Serhii Dembitskyi, “Geosocietal Support for Democracy: Survey Evidence from Ukraine,” Perspectives on Politics (April 2024) https://doi.org/10.1017/S1537592724000422.). In our statistical tests, indicators of external threat—linked to Russia’s ongoing full-scale military aggression—not only retain significance but become more salient after mid-2022 than differences in age, income, gender and education. Also in line with this logic, aspirations for EU and NATO membership (seeing Ukraine as belonging in the geopolitical West) come through as the most robust and significant predictors of democracy support, while reported past reliance on Russia as a news source diminished such support.

The project data and the findings have been used to generate peer-reviewed journal articles, conference papers and presentations, policy memos, and new undergraduate and graduate course content, with more details on the project websites in English (https://alexseev.sdsu.edu/russia-ukraine-war/) and Ukrainian (https://isnasu.org.ua/intscicoop/001_Alexeev_Hale_Dembitsky_-_Vidstezhennya_grom_dumky_v_Ukraini.php).
